thread.title_full: A lie-in and a carrier bag – Troy Deeney's big break

title: A lie-in and a carrier bag – Troy Deeney's big break
text:
“I actually did all right but not turning up didn’t set the best example and they said I wasn’t applying myself.” 
Despite his obvious talent, Deeney was soon working on a building site and turning out for Chelmsley. 
“Playing for Chelmsley was the main thing for me because the cool kids played there,” he said. “I went to college, I became a builder and then I got the trial with Walsall – but I didn’t even take that seriously.” 
Looking back, Deeney knows the the trial at Walsall was a big turning point. Matt Doherty of Wolverhampton Wanderers and Troy Deeney of Watford. 
“I thought Walsall would get rid of me but they had patience,” he said. “Initially, I still wasn’t switched on. But I’d been going to work, going in at six in the morning and coming home at eight at night. When I had a chance to get up at nine, back home for two, I wanted some of that. 
“The other lads would say to me after training, ‘I’m so tired’. I’d be sitting there going, ‘you lot for real?’ I thought I’ll make more money for less work, let’s not blow this.” 
The striker went on to score 27 goals in 123 appearances for the Saddlers before earning a £500,000 move to Watford – a deal which could still net Walsall a large sell-on fee. 
But in December 2012, eight days after his father died from cancer, Deeney was convicted of affray for his part in a street brawl in Birmingham. 
He served three months in prison. But the 27-year-old says time in jail helped turn his life around. 
“At that point I was still one of the lads,” Deeney admitted. “I was going out drinking but because I was still performing on a Saturday nobody told me to stop. 
“Then reality kicked in. I went to jail for 12 weeks, I had 300 people in my phone book, but only six people sent me letters and helped with my bills. 
“On a Saturday I had hundreds of people wanting to go out with me. 
“But when I was in prison and not being paid, there weren’t many people saying ‘here’s that £100 you sorted me out with’. I came out and it was a second chance – my mentality was that I wanted to make my son proud because he thought I was at a football camp.” 
A character reformed, Deeney is Watford captain and would command a transfer fee in excess of £10 million. More on this story:
